citations.narrative:
The three rabbit wire enclosures are in need of cleaning. All are covered in rabbit hair and debris. There is a large mound
of rabbit excreta that has accumulated in the adult rabbit enclosure. The wire of the floor of the enclosures is dirty.
Accumulation of excreta and hair can lead to odors, attract pests and possibly spread disease. Periodic cleaning and
sanitization every 30 days helps prevent these issues.
Primary enclosures shall be kept free of excreta, hair, cobwebs and other debris by periodic cleaning. Correct by 7/8/23.

Several enclosures are in need of repair.
*The enclosure in the barn housing the zebu calves have some loose wires with sharp points in the enclosure fencing.
*One side fencing panel of the nilgai enclosure is loose/leaning in toward the center of the enclosure.
*The coatimundi enclosure has some loose wire with sharp points present on the wire sides. In addition the soil has
eroded from along the sides of the interior of the enclosure leaving the buried wire exposed. The coatimundi may get a
leg/foot caught in the openings.
Housing facilities in disrepair can lead to injury or escape of the animals.
The housing facilities for all animals must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair. Correct by 8/5/23.

*The current enclosure housing the two coatimundi is not enclosed by a perimeter fence at least six feet in height and
three feet in distance from the primary enclosure fence.
*Three sides of the two enclosures, currently one housing wallaby and the other housing kangaroo and wallaby, are
surrounded by the 6 foot high perimeter fence but the fourth side is surrounded only by a four foot high fence.
A perimeter fence is necessary to keep out unauthorized animals and persons and to act as a secondary containment
fence if the animals were to get out. The facility shall build a secondary or perimeter fence for the exotic species owned at
least six feet in height and three feet in distance from the primary enclosure.

Three enclosures in the barn (one housing young zebu and calf, one housing a nilgai and one housing a water buffalo calf
and two calves) are in need of the cleaning. Excreta has built up in one corner and along one side of the nilgai enclosure.
The other two enclosures are wet/moist with dirty shavings. Many flies were noted in these areas, attracted by the dirty
shavings/excreta accumulation.
Dirty shavings and excreta accumulation will lead to odors, possible disease hazards and attract flies and other pests.
The facility shall ensure that excreta is removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination,
reduce odors and minimize disease hazards.
Correct by 7/8/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.56(a)(1) 
   
Sanitation. 
The three rabbit wire enclosures are in need of cleaning. All are covered in rabbit hair and debris. There is a large mound 
of rabbit excreta that has accumulated in the adult rabbit enclosure. The wire of the floor of the enclosures is dirty.  
Accumulation of excreta and hair can lead to odors, attract pests and possibly spread disease. Periodic cleaning and 
sanitization every 30 days helps prevent these issues.  
Primary enclosures shall be kept free of excreta, hair, cobwebs and other debris by periodic cleaning. Correct by 7/8/23. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Several enclosures are in need of repair.  
*The enclosure in the barn housing the zebu calves have some loose wires with sharp points in the enclosure fencing.  
*One side fencing panel of the nilgai enclosure is loose/leaning in toward the center of the enclosure.  
*The coatimundi enclosure has some loose wire with sharp points present on the wire sides. In addition the soil has 
eroded from along the sides of the interior of the enclosure leaving the buried wire exposed. The coatimundi may get a 
leg/foot caught in the openings.  
Housing facilities in disrepair can lead to injury or escape of the animals.  
The housing facilities for all animals must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair. Correct by 8/5/23. 
3.127(d)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
*The current enclosure housing the two coatimundi is not enclosed by a perimeter fence at least six feet in height and 
three feet in distance from the primary enclosure fence.  
*Three sides of the two enclosures, currently one housing wallaby and the other housing kangaroo and wallaby, are 
surrounded by the 6 foot high perimeter fence but the fourth side is surrounded only by a four foot high fence.  
A perimeter fence is necessary to keep out unauthorized animals and persons and to act as a secondary containment 
fence if the animals were to get out. The facility shall build a secondary or perimeter fence for the exotic species owned at 
least six feet in height and three feet in distance from the primary enclosure. 
3.131(a)

Sanitation. 
Three enclosures in the barn (one housing young zebu and calf, one housing a nilgai and one housing a water buffalo calf 
and two calves) are in need of the cleaning. Excreta has built up in one corner and along one side of the nilgai enclosure. 
The other two enclosures are wet/moist with dirty shavings. Many flies were noted in these areas, attracted by the dirty 
shavings/excreta accumulation.  
Dirty shavings and excreta accumulation will lead to odors, possible disease hazards and attract flies and other pests.  
The facility shall ensure that excreta is removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination, 
reduce odors and minimize disease hazards.  
Correct by 7/8/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
